claim: Watermelon is safe for people with a tricarboxylic acid allergy.

supporting.text: Watermelon is primarily composed of water (about 92%) and natural sugars, which are not known to trigger tricarboxylic acid allergies.

attacks.text: Watermelon is primarily composed of water (about 92%) and natural sugars, which are not known to trigger tricarboxylic acid allergies.
Some individuals with tricarboxylic acid allergies may still react to trace amounts of citric acid or malic acid present in watermelon.
Citric acid and malic acid concentrations in watermelon are typically too low to trigger allergic reactions in most people.
Allergic reactions can vary widely between individuals, and some may be highly sensitive to even minimal amounts of tricarboxylic acids.
Clinical studies show that severe reactions to tricarboxylic acids in fruits like watermelon are extremely rare.

supporting.text: Tricarboxylic acid allergies typically involve reactions to citric acid or other specific acids, none of which are present in significant amounts in watermelon.

attacks.text: Tricarboxylic acid allergies typically involve reactions to citric acid or other specific acids, none of which are present in significant amounts in watermelon.

Malic acid concentrations in watermelon are negligible and unlikely to cause allergic reactions even in sensitive individuals.
Cross-reactivity between different tricarboxylic acids is possible, meaning an allergy to one could extend to others present in watermelon.
Clinical studies show no documented cases of watermelon triggering tricarboxylic acid allergies, suggesting cross-reactivity is unlikely.

supporting.text: There is no documented evidence or medical literature linking watermelon consumption to adverse reactions in individuals with tricarboxylic acid allergies.

attacks.text: There is no documented evidence or medical literature linking watermelon consumption to adverse reactions in individuals with tricarboxylic acid allergies.

The metabolic pathway from citrulline to arginine is well-regulated in the body and unlikely to cause issues for most people with tricarboxylic acid allergies.

supporting.text: Watermelon is generally considered hypoallergenic and is often recommended as a safe fruit for people with various food allergies, including those related to acids.
